trails.name: Old Rag Mountain Trail
trails.description: One of the most popular hikes in Virginia! This challenging trail features rock scrambling, stunning 360-degree views from the summit, and passes through beautiful hardwood forests. The rock scramble section is exhilarating and suitable for confident hikers.

trails.name: McAfee Knob Trail
trails.description: The most photographed spot on the Appalachian Trail! McAfee Knob offers one of the best panoramic views in Virginia. The iconic jutting rock ledge provides an incredible photo opportunity overlooking the Catawba Valley. Best visited during sunrise or sunset.

trails.name: Dark Hollow Falls Trail
trails.description: A short but rewarding hike to a beautiful 70-foot waterfall. The trail follows a cascading stream through lush forest. Popular with families and great for a quick nature fix. The waterfall is most impressive after rainfall in spring and fall.

trails.name: Humpback Rocks Trail
trails.description: A steep but short climb to spectacular 360-degree views of the Blue Ridge Mountains. The massive rock formations at the summit are perfect for scrambling and photography. Despite its brevity, this trail packs a punch with significant elevation gain.

trails.name: Crabtree Falls Trail
trails.description: Virginia's highest vertical-drop cascading waterfall! The trail features five major cascades totaling over 1,200 feet. Well-maintained with multiple overlooks and platforms for viewing. Absolutely stunning in spring with high water flow and fall with colorful foliage.

trails.name: Spy Rock Trail
trails.description: A relatively easy hike to a fantastic rocky overlook with sweeping views of the Blue Ridge. The summit features a large rock outcropping perfect for sunset viewing. Much less crowded than nearby popular trails, offering a more peaceful mountain experience.

trails.name: Dragon's Tooth Trail
trails.description: A challenging climb to a spectacular rock monolith that juts skyward like a dragon's tooth. The final ascent requires hand-over-hand scrambling. Incredible 360-degree views from the top make this one of the most rewarding hikes in southwest Virginia.

trails.name: Whiteoak Canyon Trail
trails.description: Features six major waterfalls ranging from 35 to 86 feet. The trail is steep and rocky with several stream crossings. Absolutely gorgeous scenery throughout with lush forests and multiple swimming holes. Consider combining with Cedar Run for a challenging loop.

trails.name: Stony Man Trail
trails.description: The easiest summit in Shenandoah National Park! A gentle, nearly level trail to the second-highest peak in the park. Offers spectacular views with minimal effort. Perfect for families, seniors, or anyone wanting big views without the big climb.

trails.name: Hawksbill Mountain Trail
trails.description: The highest peak in Shenandoah National Park at 4,050 feet! Short but steady climb to a rocky summit with incredible 360-degree views. Excellent for spotting peregrine falcons and hawks. Great for sunrise or sunset photography.

trails.name: Great Falls Park - River Trail
trails.description: Experience the power of the Potomac River as it cascades over dramatic falls and rapids. Multiple overlooks provide stunning views of the falls. Rocky, rooted trail follows the river with opportunities to explore rocky islands. Very popular on weekends.

trails.name: Three Ridges Trail
trails.description: One of the toughest hikes in Virginia with over 4,000 feet of elevation gain. Features three major ridge crossings with stunning views from multiple rocky summits. Passes by beautiful waterfalls and swimming holes. Best done as a backpacking trip.

trails.name: Devil's Marbleyard Trail
trails.description: Hike to a unique geological formation: a massive boulder field covering eight acres. The white quartzite boulders create an otherworldly landscape perfect for scrambling. Great views from the top of the boulder field looking out over the valley.

trails.name: Cascade Falls Trail
trails.description: A beautiful hike through rhododendron tunnels leading to a stunning 69-foot waterfall. The trail follows Little Stony Creek through a lush gorge. The waterfall cascades over multiple tiers into a large pool below. Most impressive in spring.

trails.name: Bearfence Mountain Trail
trails.description: Short but exciting trail featuring rock scrambling to a 360-degree summit view. Despite its short length, this trail is packed with adventure. The rocky summit provides one of the best panoramic views in Shenandoah for such a short hike.

trails.name: Sharp Top Trail
trails.description: Steep climb to one of the Peaks of Otter with spectacular views of the Blue Ridge Mountains and Abbott Lake. Rocky trail with several sections requiring hands for balance. A shuttle bus is available to the summit if you prefer to hike down only.

trails.name: Tinker Cliffs Trail
trails.description: Features exposed cliffs with dramatic drop-offs and incredible valley views. Part of the Appalachian Trail, this hike offers some of the best cliff-side hiking in Virginia. Multiple viewpoints along the ridge make for great rest stops.

trails.name: Apple Orchard Falls Trail
trails.description: Beautiful waterfall hike featuring a 200-foot cascading waterfall. The trail follows North Creek through a scenic gorge with multiple smaller cascades. Can be combined with Apple Orchard Mountain for extended views from the second-highest peak in Virginia.

trails.name: Riprap Trail
trails.description: One of the most rugged and remote trails in Shenandoah National Park. Features multiple rock scrambles, swimming holes, and spectacular views from Calvary Rocks. Less crowded than most park trails, offering a true wilderness experience.

trails.name: Humpback Rocks to Paul's Gap
trails.description: Extended Humpback Rocks hike continuing along the Appalachian Trail. Features multiple ridge-top views and less crowded trails beyond the Humpback summit. Beautiful hardwood forests and wildflowers in spring. Requires shuttle or car spot.

trails.name: Mount Rogers via Appalachian Trail
trails.description: Hike to Virginia's highest point at 5,729 feet! The summit is forested but nearby Wilburn Ridge offers incredible 360-degree views. Famous for wild ponies that roam the highlands. Beautiful high-elevation meadows and unique spruce-fir forest.

trails.name: Burke Lake Trail
trails.description: Easy paved loop around beautiful Burke Lake. Perfect for families, running, or biking. Passes through varied scenery including woods and open areas. Wildlife viewing opportunities including deer, waterfowl, and various birds. Accessible trail.

trails.name: Scott's Run Nature Preserve
trails.description: Hidden gem featuring a beautiful waterfall just minutes from Washington DC. Trail follows Scott's Run through a scenic ravine to the Potomac River. Rocky sections near the waterfall. Great for a quick nature escape near the city.

trails.name: Cascades National Recreation Trail
trails.description: Popular trail leading to spectacular 66-foot waterfall. Well-maintained trail with wooden bridges and boardwalks. Multiple viewpoints of Little Stony Creek. The waterfall observation deck provides amazing views and photo opportunities.

trails.name: North Mountain Trail
trails.description: Remote trail in the George Washington National Forest offering solitude and beautiful ridge-top views. Features mixed hardwood forests and rocky outcrops. Less traveled than many Virginia trails, perfect for those seeking a quieter hiking experience.

trails.name: Fenwick Mines to Blue Hole
trails.description: Unique hike through historic mining area to beautiful Blue Hole swimming spot. Trail passes old mining ruins and follows the scenic Irish Creek. The Blue Hole is a deep, clear pool perfect for summer swimming. History and nature combined.

trails.name: Bluff Trail at Pandapas Pond
trails.description: Scenic loop circling Pandapas Pond with gentle terrain. Beautiful in fall with excellent foliage reflections in the pond. Well-marked trail through mixed forest. Great for families and a favorite with Virginia Tech students.

trails.name: Coal Hollow Trail
trails.description: Short forest loop near Virginia Tech campus. Follows cascading creek with small waterfalls. Peaceful woodland hike with several bridge crossings. Popular with locals for a quick nature break.

trails.name: Cascades at Mabry Mill
trails.description: Easy loop around the iconic Mabry Mill on the Blue Ridge Parkway. Historic working mill with beautiful pond reflections. Especially stunning in fall. Accessible trail perfect for all ages and abilities.

trails.name: Trail of the Cedars at Natural Bridge
trails.description: Short paved trail to the spectacular Natural Bridge, a 215-foot limestone arch. Easy walk through beautiful Cedar Forest. Includes the historic bridge featured on early surveys by George Washington. Great for families.

trails.name: Grayson Highlands Loop
trails.description: Beautiful highland meadows with wild ponies and spectacular views. Rocky sections with scrambling opportunities. Unique alpine environment rare in Virginia. Wildflowers bloom throughout summer. One of the most unique landscapes in the state.

trails.name: Limberlost Trail
trails.description: Wheelchair accessible trail through old-growth hemlock forest in Shenandoah. Crushed greenstone surface makes this trail easy for everyone. Peaceful forest setting with massive ancient hemlocks. Perfect for accessibility and families.

trails.name: Mount Vernon Trail
trails.description: Paved multi-use trail along the Potomac River from Mount Vernon to Theodore Roosevelt Island. Stunning views of DC monuments across the river. Popular for running and cycling. Can be done in sections for shorter distances.

trails.name: Appalachian Trail - Rockfish Gap to Calf Mountain
trails.description: Section of the AT with multiple viewpoints and gentle terrain by AT standards. Features Bear Den Mountain and Calf Mountain summits. Good introduction to the Appalachian Trail. Beautiful in all seasons.

trails.name: Jones Run Falls Trail
trails.description: Steep descent to a beautiful 42-foot waterfall in Shenandoah. The trail is more challenging on the return uphill. Less crowded than other Shenandoah waterfalls. Best visited in spring for maximum water flow.

trails.name: Overall Run Falls Trail
trails.description: Hike to Shenandoah's tallest waterfall at 93 feet! Challenging trail with significant elevation change. The upper and lower falls are both spectacular. Rocky, root-filled trail requiring good footwear. Worth every bit of effort.

trails.name: Rose River Falls Loop
trails.description: Lovely loop featuring beautiful waterfall and scenic creek views. Well-maintained trail through lush forest. The falls cascade gracefully over rock ledges. One of the more popular family-friendly hikes in Shenandoah.

trails.name: South River Falls Trail
trails.description: Third-highest waterfall in Shenandoah at 83 feet. Steep descent to the falls with spectacular views from multiple viewpoints. The trail continues below the falls for a unique perspective looking up at the cascade.

trails.name: Skyline to Old Rag Circuit
trails.description: Extended Old Rag adventure combining the classic scramble with ridge-top hiking. Very challenging with significant elevation gain and technical rock sections. For experienced hikers only. Incredible ridge views throughout.

trails.name: Trayfoot Mountain Trail
trails.description: Less-traveled trail in Shenandoah offering solitude and wildlife viewing opportunities. Gradual climb through beautiful hardwood forest to mountain summit. Great for those seeking to escape crowds.

trails.name: Dismal Falls Trail
trails.description: Very short hike to a beautiful 15-foot waterfall along the Appalachian Trail. Easy access makes this perfect for families and a quick nature break. Swimming hole at base of falls popular in summer. Despite the name, the falls are anything but dismal!

trails.name: Channels at Clinch Mountain
trails.description: Unique geological formation featuring narrow channels between massive sandstone boulders. Ice can remain in the channels year-round! Short but fascinating hike through otherworldly landscape. Great for rock scrambling.

trails.name: Hidden Valley Trail
trails.description: Beautiful valley hike through George Washington National Forest. Follows bubbling creek through hemlock groves and hardwood forest. Several small waterfalls and swimming holes. Peaceful and less crowded.

trails.name: Wild Oak Trail
trails.description: Epic mountain bike and hiking trail through remote wilderness. Can be done as multi-day backpack or very long day hike. Features streams, ridges, and extensive forest. One of Virginia's premier long-distance trails.

trails.name: Cole Mountain Trail
trails.description: Unique bald mountain with 360-degree views and wildflower meadows. Gentle terrain despite elevation. One of the few natural balds in Virginia. Spectacular in late spring and summer when wildflowers bloom.

trails.name: Sugarloaf Mountain Trail
trails.description: Isolated mountain rising above Maryland piedmont with excellent views. Multiple trail options to summit. Rocky scramble near top. Popular spot close to DC metro area. Great for sunset viewing.

trails.name: Billy Goat Trail - Section A
trails.description: Technical rock scrambling trail along the Potomac River. Most challenging section near DC. Requires good balance and isn't recommended in wet conditions. Spectacular views of Mather Gorge and Great Falls. Extremely popular.

trails.name: Annapolis Rock via Appalachian Trail
trails.description: Popular AT section leading to expansive rock outcrop with panoramic views. Moderate climb through beautiful forest. The rock ledge is perfect for sunset watching. Can continue to Black Rock for additional views.

trails.name: Catoctin Mountain Trail
trails.description: Lovely forest loop through Catoctin Mountain Park. Features multiple waterfalls including Cunningham Falls. Rocky sections with moderate elevation change. Beautiful in all seasons especially fall foliage.

trails.name: Maryland Heights Trail
trails.description: Steep climb to spectacular overlook of Harpers Ferry and river confluence. Historic Civil War ruins along trail. The view from the top is one of the best in the mid-Atlantic. Challenging but incredibly rewarding.

trails.name: Raven Rock Trail
trails.description: Section of the AT to impressive rock outcrop with views of the Shenandoah Valley. Moderate climb with rocky sections. The rock formation itself is dramatic and offers multiple viewpoints. Less crowded than nearby trails.

trails.name: Seneca Creek Trail
trails.description: Beautiful creek-side trail with numerous waterfalls and swimming holes. Relatively gentle terrain following the scenic creek. Multiple campsites for backpacking. One of the prettiest creek hikes in West Virginia.

trails.name: Seneca Rocks Trail
trails.description: Short but steep climb to observation platform below the famous Seneca Rocks. Incredible views of the dramatic 900-foot quartzite rock formation. Watch rock climbers scaling the face. Platform provides safe viewing.

trails.name: Dolly Sods Wilderness
trails.description: Unique high-elevation plateau with cranberry bogs and windswept plains. Feels like hiking in Canada! Rocky, sometimes wet terrain. Spectacular views from Bear Rocks. Multiple trail combinations possible. True wilderness experience.

trails.name: Blackwater Falls Trail
trails.description: Short paved trail to stunning 57-foot waterfall. The amber-colored water (from tannic acid) is unique and beautiful. Accessible boardwalk to multiple viewpoints. Great for families and photographers. Stunning in winter when frozen.

trails.name: Lindy Point Trail
trails.description: Easy trail to breathtaking overlook in Blackwater Canyon. Sheer cliffs drop 1,500 feet to the canyon floor. Sunrise here is spectacular. Short enough for all abilities but dramatic views rival much longer hikes.

trails.name: Spruce Knob Trail
trails.description: Short loop at West Virginia's highest point (4,863 feet). Unique high-elevation spruce forest ecosystem. Observation tower provides 360-degree views. Often cool even in summer. Easy hike with big rewards.

trails.name: Cathedral Falls Trail
trails.description: Roadside waterfall with very short walk from parking. Beautiful 60-foot falls cascading over rock ledges. Quick stop that packs a visual punch. Perfect for those who can't do longer hikes but want to see waterfalls.

trails.name: Endless Wall Trail
trails.description: Rim trail above New River Gorge with multiple overlooks of the dramatic gorge and bridge. Watch rock climbers on the cliff face. Relatively easy walking with spectacular views. Don't miss Diamond Point overlook.

trails.name: Long Point Trail at New River Gorge
trails.description: Most popular hike in New River Gorge leading to iconic overlook of the bridge. Gentle forest trail ending at dramatic cliff-top view. The perspective of the steel arch bridge from here is unforgettable. Go for sunset if possible.

trails.name: Chimney Tops Trail
trails.description: Strenuous hike to twin rocky peaks in the Smoky Mountains. Final ascent involves scrambling up bare rock faces. Incredible 360-degree views from summits. Very popular so arrive early. Affected by 2016 fires but recovering beautifully.

trails.name: Alum Cave Trail to Mount LeConte
trails.description: Classic Smoky Mountains hike passing Arch Rock, Alum Cave Bluffs, and climbing to LeConte Lodge. Dramatic features throughout including narrow ledges with cable handrails. Challenging but scenic every step of the way.

trails.name: Laurel Falls Trail
trails.description: Paved trail to beautiful 80-foot waterfall in the Smokies. Most popular waterfall hike in the park due to accessibility. Upper and lower cascades visible from viewing area. Can be crowded but worth it for the waterfall.

trails.name: Rainbow Falls Trail
trails.description: Popular trail to spectacular 80-foot waterfall. The falls often produce rainbows in afternoon light (hence the name). Moderate climb through beautiful old-growth forest. Can be wet and slippery near the falls.

trails.name: Clingmans Dome Trail
trails.description: Paved trail to highest point in the Smokies and Tennessee (6,643 feet). Observation tower provides 360-degree views. Can see seven states on clear days. Steep but short. Often cool and foggy creating atmospheric conditions.

trails.name: Andrews Bald Trail
trails.description: Hike to beautiful grassy bald with 360-degree mountain views. One of only two balds maintained in the Smokies. Spectacular flame azaleas bloom in June. Relatively easy high-elevation hike starting from Clingmans Dome.

trails.name: Abrams Falls Trail
trails.description: Moderate hike to most voluminous waterfall in the Smokies. The 20-foot falls may not be the tallest but has incredible water volume. Beautiful large pool at base. Trail follows scenic creek through forest.

trails.name: Charlies Bunion Trail
trails.description: Appalachian Trail hike to dramatic rocky outcrop with stunning views. The 'bunion' is a narrow rock spine with sheer drop-offs. One of the best views in the Smokies. Cooler temperatures at high elevation.

trails.name: Grotto Falls Trail
trails.description: Unique trail that goes behind a 25-foot waterfall! Only waterfall in the Smokies you can walk behind. Beautiful forest setting with old-growth hemlocks. Popular with families and great for photos from behind the veil of water.

trails.name: Mount Mitchell Trail
trails.description: Hike to the highest peak east of the Mississippi (6,684 feet)! Challenging climb through beautiful spruce-fir forest. Observation tower at summit provides incredible views. Often much cooler than valleys below.

trails.name: Linville Gorge Trail
trails.description: Rugged trail through wilderness area known as the Grand Canyon of the East. Dramatic gorge views and challenging rocky terrain. Remote and wild feeling. Multiple viewpoint options. Spectacular but strenuous.

trails.name: Linville Falls Trail
trails.description: Short trail to multiple overlooks of spectacular multi-tiered waterfall. Upper and lower falls viewpoints accessible. Falls drop into dramatic Linville Gorge. Easy access to impressive scenery makes this very popular.

trails.name: Grandfather Mountain Trail
trails.description: Exciting trail to rocky summit with incredible views and famous Mile High Swinging Bridge. Dramatic rock formations and ladders. Outstanding 360-degree views. Private park with entrance fee but well-maintained facilities.

trails.name: Looking Glass Rock Trail
trails.description: Steep climb to bare granite dome offering spectacular views. The massive rock face is popular with rock climbers. Summit provides 360-degree panoramas. Strenuous but the views are worth every step.

trails.name: Sliding Rock Trail
trails.description: Natural waterslide over smooth rock into pool below. More of an activity than a hike! 60-foot natural slide is thrilling and refreshing. Very popular in summer. Lifeguards on duty. Unique natural experience.

trails.description: A beautiful easy trail featuring stunning views and natural beauty. Perfect for hikers seeking adventure in Alabama.

reviews.comment: Absolutely stunning! The views from the summit were worth every step. The rock scramble was exhilarating and suitable for confident hikers. Trail was well-marked and maintained. Bring plenty of water as there's no shade on the upper section. Highly recommend starting early!

The most iconic view on the Appalachian Trail! Worth the hike just for the photo opportunity. Trail is well-maintained with steady elevation gain. Best visited during sunrise or sunset. Parking lot fills up quickly on weekends, arrive early!

Beautiful waterfall and a great short hike for families. The trail follows a cascading stream through lush forest. Popular spot but worth it. The waterfall was impressive even in drier conditions. Kids loved it!

Challenging but incredibly rewarding! The final scramble to the tooth is exhilarating. 360-degree views from the top are breathtaking. Trail is rocky and steep in sections. Bring gloves for the scramble. This is now one of my favorite hikes!

Virginia's highest waterfall did not disappoint! Multiple cascades along the trail with several viewing platforms. Well-maintained trail with steady elevation gain. Absolutely stunning in spring with high water flow. A must-visit waterfall trail!
Beautiful falls and easy access from DC area. Great for a quick nature escape. Trail has multiple overlooks of the falls. Can get crowded on weekends. Perfect for families and beginners.

Short but steep! Amazing views from the top. The rock formations at the summit are perfect for photos. Trail is well-marked but challenging. Great workout in a short distance. Highly recommend for sunset!

Six beautiful waterfalls! Steep and rocky trail with several stream crossings. Lush forest scenery throughout. Perfect for hot summer days with multiple swimming holes. One of Shenandoah's best waterfall hikes!
